LONDON, Printed for R. M. and are to bee sold in Saint Dunstanes Church-yard. 1629.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE EARLE OF SOMMERSET, &c.
div.p: YOu read this Tragedie, and smil'd vpon't, that it might liue: and therein, your mercy was diuine; for it exceeded Iustice. My Numbers I not shew vnto the publike Eye, with an ambition to bee quickly knowne; (for so I couet noyse, not fame) but that the world may learne, with what an early haste, I striue to manifest my seruice to your Lordship. I haue imaginations of a greater height then these, which I doe also dedicate to your Lordship. And I shall liue in vaine, vnlesse you still continue to acknowledge

div.head: VPON THE TRAGICK MVSE OF MY HONOVR'D FRIEND, Mr. Wm. D'AVENANT.
div.l: OVr stately Tragick Scene (whose high disdaines
Slight humble Muses) courts thy lofty straines:
And with ambitious loue doth clime thy Bayes,
Whose ample branches her bright glory rayes:
Whence (as from Heauen) her spacious Eye doth view
Of storyed teares, and blood, the heauy crue,
How low they crawle, while she (farre more Diuine!)
Sides great Seianus, and fierce Cateline:
Where, in calme vertue, she more sweet doth shew
Then Ioue, when he in Golden drops did flow:
But if in Stygian Lake her veines she steepe,
Her act infernall runnes so horrid deepe,
As saints Medea: makes th' Herculian rage
Seeme a tame patience to thy rauisht Stage.
Had sterne Achilles brest such fury knowne;
His Story had turn'd Miracle, and growne
Too much for his great Poet, vnlesse Fate
Had rackt his spirit vp to thy high rate.
Rash Imitation at thy heauenly Ayre,
Intombes faint Enuy in a iust despaire.

div.head: To his friend, Mr. Wm. D'auenant.
div.l: WHy should the fond ambition of a friend,
With such Industrious accents striue to lend
A Prologue to thy worth? Can ought of mine
Inrich thy Volume? Th' hast rear'd thy selfe a Shrine
Will out-liue Piramids; Marble Pillars shall,
Ere thy great Muse, receiue a funerall:
Thy wit hath purchas'd such a Patrons name
To deck thy front, as must deriue to Fame
These Tragick raptures, and indent with Eyes
To spend hot teares, t'inrich the Sacrifice.

div.head: To my honor'd Friend, th'Author, on his Tragedy of the warlike Albouine.
div.l: GReat Albouine, whose Fate in warre had cut
His passage through the neighb'ring Earth, and shut
Large Prouinces within his grasping palme,
Had sunke from honour in the patient calme
Of a long silenc't Fame, had not thy pen
(With soaring language) rays'd him vp agen.
He vowes, by coole Elizeum (from whence
He breath'd the valiant oath) he would dispense
With all those ioyes that court his soule, to fling
His open'd brest vpon the poys'nous sting
Of rougher warres, if the triumphant Bayes
Sprung from thy inke, might crowne his second prayse.
This is a Poets height; conquest by thee
Describ'd, becomes a double victory.

div.head: To my deseruing Friend, the Author.

lg.l: WEre those Tragedians, whom the world so fame,
For their ingenious and admired straine,
Aliue, to see this Poem, and thy Name;
Asham'd they'd dye, finding their Lines too vaine.
Were that pure Spring the winged hoofe brought forth,
Wanting supply, dry'd vp, thy abler Pen
Would worke a second wonder by it's worth,
In making it a running streame agen.
Be then assur'd, this Tragick straine shall liue
A patterne for th' next age to imitate,
And to the best wits of our times shall giue
Iust cause of enuy, for thy learned Fate.

div.head: To his noble Friend, th'Author on his Tragedy of Albouine.
div.l: THe gelid North growes warme, and by thy fire
Cold ignorance exil'd. The Virgin Quire
O' th' soft-hayr'd Muses leaue the Thespian Spring,
To tread a fun'rall Measure, whilst you sing
This Tragick Storie. With sad plaints of loue
Fam'd Orpheus charm'd rude heapes, did Cedars mooue,
Forc'd Mountaines from their station: but thy Pen
Hath now amaz'd the firie soules of men.

div.head: To my Friend, Mr. D'auenant.
div.l: SCarce home return'd, but straight I finde great Fame
Ayring her wings to spread abroad thy Name.
One of the Nine (before of me ne'r seene,
Sure sent by thee) assaults my merry spleene
With mighty Verse; and makes me laugh at those
That are so dull, to melt their thoughts in Prose.
I wish her prosp'rous flight, may she returne
With happier wings, if happier may be worne.
My flame is spent. I dare not vndertake
Thy praise, who am but newly for thy sake
A fierce Poet, and doubtlesse had been one
Ne'r but for thee, or else had been vnknowne.

div.head: To his much-honour'd friend, the Author.
div.l: LEt not loud Enuy's sulph'rous blasts cast forth
Venom'd aspersions, on thy noble worth:
'Gainst saucy Criticks thou need'st no defence,
Whose sacred lines, arm'd with sweet eloquence,
Are proofe against their censures, whoo'd prophane.
With their bold breath, the glory of thy straine:
Wise came shall sing the prayse of thy deserts,
And voyce thee glorious both in Armes and Arts.
Whilst thou, releast from the Warres sad mishaps,
Rests in soft dalliance on the Muses laps;
Those beautious Ladies loue shall high aduance
Thy fame, whose worth exceeds my vtterance.
Their Tragicke falles, who in thy Scenes appeare,
Shall on these Monuments faire Trophees reare
Vnto their Fame. Thus are thy workes become
To be to them, as their Elizium.

div.head: To his worthy friend, Mr. Wm. D'auenant.
div.l: HAst thou vnmaskt thy Muse? And shall the Aire
Breathe on her matchlesse Fabrick? then repaire.
To some soft censure, lest the churlish sence
Of Ignorance accrues thy recompence;
And hudwinkt Error doe surprize the Fame
Due to thy Story, and Verona's name,
Whose limits Plinies and Catullus bred,
But in thy Muse her ioyes are centupled:
For her inuention, truth, rare wit, and state;
Copper-lac'd Christians cannot personate.
Her Tragick Scenes, like well-tun'd Chimes ith' Skie,
Leaue Time loud Ecchoes of thy memorie.

list.item: Paradine, A captiue Souldier, his Fauourite.

body.head: THE TRAGEDY OF ALBOVINE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS.

div.head: Act the first. Scene first.
div.stage: Enter Paradine, Grimoald, Gondibert; the Drummes ceasing.

sp.speaker: Paradine.
sp.p: Giue the word aloud?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Stand?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: 1. Stand! 2. Stand! 3. Stand!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Our motion has been swift: wee
out-march Time.
Verona, (which with the mornings dim eye
We seem'd to view like Landschaip, afarre off)
Is our full obiect now. She must repent;
Our King is Steward vnto Fate; the world
Receiue from him their destinies.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Sure, the Gouernour sleepes. My Lord, is't fit
We waite vpon such Silkewormes, crepp'd in wooll?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Since we attaind the Towne not by assault,
But composition free, he shall expresse
Humilitie enough to meet vs at the Gate.

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Here comes Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Haile, young souldier! My noble Paradine!
The King must hold my nature much excus'd,
If I do greet his safe approach with loue,
Lesse violent then I expresse to thy
Rich soule. I am resolu'd thou art in health,
And fauour with thy starres.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Ere I returne your kinde salute, I would
After your faire charge inquire. Say the Queene
Smiles in captiuitie, my Valdaura
Hurts not her health with griefe; then I haue heard
Enough to make me cherish life.

sp.speaker: Hermig.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth become her title
And her birth. Since depriu'd of popular
Homage, she hath been Queene ore her great selfe.
In this captiuity nere passionate
But when she heares me name the King, and then
Her passions not of anger taste, but loue:
Loue of her Conquerour: he that in fierce
Battaile (when the Cannons sulpherous breath
Clouded the day) her noble Father slew:
Our Royall Master once; now sunke into
His soyle; where like the Lilly wither'd,
He neuer shall renew his growth agen.
My memory disturbes my Tongue! Your faire
Valdaura makes the Queene her rare and iust
Example, and is in patience skilfull.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Know, Hermegild, no hasty minute pass'd
(Since their captiuitie) wherein I fail'd
To be a sutor to the King for both.
But he's in kindnesse prompt, and still doth speake
Like Musicke, when he Rhodolinda names:
You heare tis his edict we call her Queene?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Thy vanquish'd Country owes vnto thy fame
A tall Pyramid! The captiu'd virgins
Of our Nation shall in their last Dirges
Sing thy prayse with mirth. O, I could grow old
Within thy sight. Something we now must talke
Together, and heauen will listen to't,
As to the breath of Saints—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I knew we should haue vse of conference:
Which made me begge the leading of the Vanne,
The more t'assist our opportune meeting.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Afford your eares in priuat.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Though Paradine looke flourishing, and like
A thing new brush'd; a flame of triumph,
(As if his father surfetted in some
O're-growne City when he got him) yet he
Hath in him seeds of warre, bold thoughts, and we
I'th Campe, esteeme him honest too.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: He is our Kings Minion, sleepes in his bosome.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, & the Royall foole greets him with such
Rauenous kisses, that you would thinke, he meant
To eate his lips.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: The Captiue captiuates the Conquerour.
Three Moones haue not expir'd their vsuall change,
Since he was prisoner to the King; though now
His Fauorite.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Th'art too loud! If thou'lt talke safely, go get
A sore throat; hoarce men speake low.
The captiu'd Rhodolinda, (whose father
Albouine depriu'd of life and kingdome)
Hath with such amorous subtiltie behau'd
Her gesture, that Albouine is now her
Prisoner. This martiall progresse was but made
To visit her. She makes him guilty of
Idolatry, and knowes the thrifty vse
Of time: as she ascends, her Countrimen
Must rise.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: You haue call'd that Hermegild her Creature?

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: He was her fathers Councellor; a man
Created in the darke: he walkes inuisibly;
He dwels in Labyrinths; he loues silence:
But when he talkes, his language carries more
Promiscuous sense, then ancient Oracles.
So various in his shapes, that oft he is
Disguiz'd from his owne knowledge. An error
Much incident to humane Politicks,
Who striue to know others more then themselues.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Obserue their complement.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.l: Pox o' these French ligges? Courtiers alwaies dance.
This is to Hermegild meere lechery:
This wanton gesture doth obscure
Thoughts of such consequence and weight, as hang
Like Plummets on his heart. Paradine is
A soft, easie foole, and must be guld.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my sweet Lord—

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: Now the Motion speakes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Such indeerements would too much impouerish
My gratitude: yet, tis meet our actions
Carry smooth equalitie: your consent
Must further all my Sutes You are the Kings
Iewell, and hang richly in his eare.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: You are precious vnto her, whom loud noise
Already calls our Queene: faire Rhodolinda!
We may (if they prooue naturall and kinde)
Gouerne the Nation that hath conquered vs;
Gaine our Countrey liberty, and yet
Not stray from noble Arts: such hopes our free
Imbraces prophecy. The King.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Your Troopes (Sir) are so diuided into
Mix'd files, that to the City you doe march
Betweene thick walles of men.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let my Horse-guard bring vp the Rere. We'le sport
With warre. We haue no vse of safety now,
But of magnificence.

sp.speaker: Vollterri.
sp.l: The order is already giuen. It was
Your Royall will, we hasten in our March,
Therefore each Squadron double their paces.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: My Boy, I bring thee home my chiefe Trophy:
Thou dost delight me more then victory.
Retire. I am in loue too violent.
My embraces crush thee, thou art but yet
Of tender growth—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My Countriman would kisse your Royal hands,
And then expect no greater happinesse
Till he arriue in heauen. He hath done your
Rhodolinda seruice— Presents Hermeg. on his knee to the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Rhodolinda is your humblest captiue.
She inserts you often in her prayers,
And call'd it my chiefe duty to present
Her true seruice to your Maiesty.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Her name doth inrich our Language. My boy
Can witnesse that I loue her: she makes me
Prattle in my sleepe: I'ue drunke Mandragora,
To become drowzie, in hope that I might
Dreame of her. Rise, and expect Honour.

sp.speaker: Gouernour.
sp.l: High and sacred Maiesty! Verona
Hath vnhindg'd her wide Gates: proud to admit
The fate of Kingdomes. Our crooked Matrones
Forget their age: and (as the ragged Earth
At the Springs warme approach) look fresh, & young,
To intertaine you. Our timorous Virgins
(With the bold Youth) ioyne in one wanton Quire
To sing your welcome.

sp.speaker: Grimo.
sp.p: How the Spaniell fawnes, 'cause he dares not barke?

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Th'amorous Vine clips not the shady Poplar
With such regard (about whose mossie waste
She hangs a smiling Louer.) Our City is
By the reflection of your blest approach
Like Pelion deck'd, whom Tython's Mistresse
(Leauing the weeping East) with brightnesse guilds.
There's not a wrinkle left in all Verona,
Wherein pale sorrow, or rebellious enuy
Can finde their loathed Mansion. Flattering ioy
Swells big each loyall bosome. All implore
You as their safety; who hath hush'd the noise
Of discord, and loud warre.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The Rascall flatters, as if he had seru'd
His prentiship in Court.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Th'ast done me iustice, Gouernor, & know'st
The way to make me thankefull, but not proud.
I vnderstand thou hast with honor'd safety
Preseru'd those Iewels to thy charge committed,
(My Rhodolinda, and my Boys Valdaura.)
And so increas'd new motiues of our thanks.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.l: Heauen has made your memory too humble,
Thus to record your creatures seruice.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let now the knotty Laborer rust with ease,
And aloud proclaime, that the vpland Boore
Release his Teeme, and his industrious Plough.
Let him sing glad Iös to the rustick
Powers that guard his fields, and vnto me.

sp.speaker: Gouern.
sp.l: It is by you we are: no warlike Ram,
Nor battering engine forc'd a bloody entrance
Through our thicke walls. It was the powerfull breath
Of your victorious fame, that conquer'd vs.
To that we yeelded: which as a rough blast
That poasts from the cold Artick Pole, hath borne
Before it captiu'd Nations.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: By heauen a good old man! if he be learn'd,
Ile haue him write my Annales.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Indeed he lookes like a Chronicler.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Paradine? Informe him of my deeds.
Thou hast beheld my discipline full of
Shape and order, when confusion did oppresse
The foe, and stifled them in throngs. Hah! Looke!
Rhodolinda's come to guild our Triumph!

div.stage: Enter Rhodolinda, Valdaura, Thesina, and Attendants in mourning.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: And my Valdaura too! let Nature shew
A third obiect so delightfull, we'le sweare
She is not old, nor her first materials
Wasted, but in creation still retaines
Her former strength and skill.

sp.speaker: Albou
sp.l: But why (my beautious Captiue) art thou still
In Sables wrapp'd?

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Your starres bid you be happy. My crosse fate
Like the Rauen, croaks a funerall note:
This swarthy habit, but paints forth the griefe
That chaines my soule in darknesse. And filiall loue
Commands me mourne for him, whom you too soone
Depriu'd of life, my conquer'd father.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Let his ashes rest
At quiet in their Vrne. His ghost long since
Hath wash'd away the memory of his fate
In slow-pac'd Laethe. Take me, modest faire,
Into thy bosome. O hide me there!
My glad soule, how full is thy content?
Now thou fear'd thing, that guid'st the heauenly Empire,
Rend all the murmuring clouds, and dart
Thy Thunder at me: I am safe.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: My captiuity must needs seeme easie,
Whilst the Conquerour proues so kinde.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I could gaze thus on thee, till my wonder
Did conuert me into marble; and yet
My soule would in her selfe retaine a fire,
Liuely as that which bold Prometheus stole.
Were the Sea coagulate, and the world
Returnd to th' antick Chaos, a blinde Lumpe;
Thy looke would force the warring elements
Into a sacred order; and beget
A harmony like this they now inioy.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: You are too powerfull in you speech.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Yet when I valew thus thy excellence,
Let me not forget my owne high being.
I'ue humbled all the Nations of the earth;
Brought home as spoyles the whole wealth of Nature:
Yet, Rhodolinda, nought like thee. Let me
Whisper my content, for soft musicke most
Delights the female eare. They walke aside.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Why, my deare Valdaura, dost thou suspect
My warme embraces? Let hungry death ceaze
On my honour, before it ceaze on me,
If in my brest I intertaine a thought
Vnlawfull.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I esteeme you (Sir) a friend to vertue,
And in that hope would cherish all your loue.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: In thy faire brow, there's such a Legend writ
Of timorous chastitie, that it doth blinde
Th'adulterous Eye. Not the Mountaine Ice,
(Congeal'd to Christall) is so frosty chaste
As thy victorious soule, which conquers Man,
And Mans proud Tyrant-passion. But I am
Too rough for Courtship, the soft harmony
Which wanton Peace instructs the Tongue to make,
I haue forgot. Trust me (bright Maid!)
I loue thee dearely. Though I'ue found thy heart
Like Pibble, smooth, but stony.

sp.speaker: Valda.
sp.l: I'ue heard my mother say: the curled Youth
Of Italy, were prompt in wanton stealths,
And sinfull Arts. Till Time had giuen me
Assurance of your noble thoughts; 'twas safe
To doubt your loue. But now I wish I were
More worthy, and then would prooue more liberall
Of my selfe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Let me enioy thy hand! that moyst Adamant
That so attracts my soule! We will (ere night
Her black Curtaine drawes) make compleat this loue,
With marriage Rites.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: How now, Boy! Is my interest so decay'd
In your young person, that you giue away your selfe
Without my leaue!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Humbly on my knee, I beg the vulgar
Priuiledge due to all hearts. To loue, and not enioy,
Is a torture, I cannot suffer long,
And still remaine possess'd with breath.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Thou hast shew'd me physick for my passion.
Take him, Valdaura, and be proud! Tis I
That loue him: nor shall your ioyes be single.
Ile make the number yet more full. This day
We'le consecrate to Hymens vse. Behold
Your Queene (who though my Captiue) for her birth
And beauty, is the first of Queenes.

sp.speaker: Gouer.
sp.p: High Heauen increase your ioyes!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: And may you liue together vntill Time
Shall sicken with his age.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Long liue Albouine, King of the Lombards!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Cry vp Rhodolinda too!

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Conrad. Liue Rhodolinda, Queene of the Lombards!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Gouernor! Tis our will that you expect
Honour, and true safety. Your Cities loue
I shall perceiue by popular noise, and your
Behauiour in this great solemnitie.
Let the Sunne smile; the Winde sport with our Plumes!
This day let sick-men too forget to groane.
Let all glad Hymnes in one mix'd concord sound,
And make the ecchoing heauen your mirth rebound.

div.stage: Exeunt all, but Grimold, Vollterri, Gondibert.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: The King's head must now conuert to rotten wood.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Why, Grimold?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That Court Earewiggs may liue there, and deuoure
His brains. Dost not perceiue how they begin
To creepe into his eares?

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Generous soules are still most subiect to
Credulitie.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He is a Germane in his drinke: busied
With a wanton pride, which his Flatterers
Admire for mirth, but his friends doe pitie.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.p: He should be told his sinnes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: By whom? Vollterri, now the King forsakes
The Campe, he must maintaine luxurious mouthes,
Such as can vtter perfum'd breath, and these
Straite compose a faction, engrosse his eares.
They limit still his conuersation.
Euen as the slow finger of the Diall
Doth in its motion circular remoue
To distant figures: so by a subtill
Leasure, they doe prefix the houres,
When he must change his rotten Parasite,
For one more skilfull, how t'admire, and praise.
No honest Tongue can euer interpose
To tell him he is mortall.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: It is the chiefe misery of Princes,
Nere to vnderstand their owne crimes, to sinne
In ignorance.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: True, his Confessor, that in sight externe
A Patriarke seemes, will gaine by flattery,
And superscribe vnto the King, as to the Pope
(His holinesse.) But Gondibert,
Whom Conclaues here in Court doe canonize
For Saints, will scarce be admitted in heauen
For Angels.

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Now Rhodolinda is become his Riuall
In high Soueraigntie, she will permit
No errors but her owne: The King must mend
What she mislikes.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She giues vs leasure to expect
Her character. Women make themselues more known
When they doe rule, then when th'obey.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Valdaura is inrich'd with a sweetnesse
So religious, that Paradine must sinne
In priuate, or need no mercy.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Th'ast nam'd her! Though my obdurate sufferance
In actiue warre hath quite depriu'd me of
All amorous gesture. Though not these forty
Winters, I haue seene any of her sex
But Suttlers wiues, who, in stead of Fillets,
Wrap their sooty haire in Horses girts. Though
My marrow is frozen in my bones,
Yet I melt before her eyes. When I see her,
I grow proud below the Nauell. For she
Is none o' th' French Noursery, that practice
The sublime friske. None o' your jigging Girles,
That pearch Paraqueeto's on their fists,
And ride toth' Court like Venus Falconers.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Grimold, hoarce men speake low, thou hast not caught
A cold yet.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: She's none of those that on their heads aduance
High, swagg'ring Plumes, like a gay Forehorse
In a Country Teeme. O, she's worth the tempting!

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Dost thou so commend her vertues, and yet
Wouldst thou tempt her vnto vice?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: That's a trick I learnt of the deuill. Those
That are vertuous, need his temptation,
The wicked haue power enough to damne themselues.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.l: Hark how they showte! Away Grimold, or we
Shall lose the Triumph!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Roome for Cuckolds, whose hornes are so high,
They bore the Moone, as she friskes in the skie!

div.head: Act the second. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: This Peace makes me rotten, dusty
As a Cobweb. I liue like a Cricket
ith' corner of an Ouen. Pox o' these oregrowne
Cities. To be valiant here, is to forfeit
The Statute: and these furr'd gownes hold,
There is no sinne so great as pouerty.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Thou art as melancholy as a leane Iudge!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I, or a corrupted Officer, at the noise
Of a Parliament. In this diuision
Of vnualewed Tropheys, Territories
Vast and ample, (gain'd partly by my sweat)
Not a single Acre falls to my share.

div.stage: Enter Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade, Seruants with a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Beare back there! They thrust as if they meant
To get me with child—

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: You sirrah! d'ye get the Kings officer
With child?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Beare back there! or we'le put ye to the charge
Of Surgery—

sp.speaker: Cuni.
sp.p: Dispatch, fellowes!

sp.speaker: Gondib.
sp.p: Is not that Cunymond?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: The same. He is a great Astrologer.
The meere Anotamy i'th front o'th Kalender.
You may know where the Signe is, by some toy
In's habit, which he remoues, as the Signe
Remoues.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Frollo, did they enter here by your permission?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Not by mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Nor yours, Conrade?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: They are men of China for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Then they must out. Gentlemen, pray auoide
The Presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: 'S death Sir! d'ye make vs your Voyders?

sp.speaker: Vollter.
sp.l: Must we carry away your Cheese-parings?
Thrust your Bodkins forth!

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: Draw i'th Presence? Art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: How he stands? he is created of Starch,
And dares not vse a boysterous motion,
Lest he should fall in Rumples.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Sir, you may speake like a Cannon! but you
Shall either goe, or—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Or what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Or stay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: By heauen he shall doe one, Sir—

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Nay, Captaine, doe not look, as if y'had drunk
Vineger. You must, or go, or— stay Sir—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Hey! we are tumbling in a Drum.
Within .Fellowes o' the Guard, make way there! Officers!
Open the doore—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Beare back there! Gentlemen! what d'ye meane?
Pray' beare back—

div.stage: Enter Albouine, Rhodolinda, Paradine, Valdaura, Hermegild, Thesina, &c.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Phoebus will be thought more rash then Phaeton,
If now he hasten to the West. Sir, this
Glorious day, merits well a longer age,
Then what is limitted to all within
Our Kalender.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, thy free heart adds to our triumph!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, I'ue some few words, I needs must vtter:
Since my last seruices in Hungary,
You remaine on my Tally six thousand
Duckats: I'm loth to skore vp still, and pay
My selfe with my owne Chalke.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Wouldst haue thy Soule dismissed a naturall way?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I would not starue, looke, like a parch'd Anotamy
Sow'd in a Kid-skin. Pay your debts, Sir!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I neuer met with boldnesse, vntill now!
My courage is quite puzled!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Do your eares blister to heare this? My breath is
Wholsome. I cannot tipple like a Duck
In a greene Poole. Nor feed on Berries in
A Hedge, like some lost remnant o' my fathers
Scatterd lust. Sir, pay your debts!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Sure, thou art some spirit! I cannot kill thee!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this diuision of the Lands, I help'd
To conquer; I am not furnish'd with
A Mole-hill for a pillow.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild sat chiefe in the Committee
For diuision of those Lands: bid him reward
Your seruice: besides, I mistake the custome,
Or tis my Treasurers office to pay
My debts, not mine.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: No Sir, (thanks to your Royall thrift) it is
Your office to pay all; your Treasurers
Custome to pay nothing. Thrusts him away.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Do not interrupt my marriage Rites!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I cannot take your reference for paiment.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Would thou wert dead!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Sir, Ile make my Ghost, my Executor,
And walke after death, ere Ile lose my mony.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Sit, my Rhodolinda: This is thy Spheare!
In th'absence of the Sunne, we must receiue
Our light from thee. Paradine, thy Bride expects
Thy seruice.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sh'as an ill bargaine on't, to rule one night,
And euer after to obey.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Captaine, though the King be prompt in mercy,
Yet hath he so much anger in him,
As will expresse him mortall. Tis for your
Safety, to auoid the Presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Ile bribe your Lordship with a Ginny Tooth-pick!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You must repent this language.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: He must not, Hermegild!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: These whom you number in your faction,
Enioy, by your assistance, proud structures;
And fertill Granges, to maintaine their gaudy
Riot. Sir, you had a fraile memory,
Or a degenerate heart, when you forgot
His merit; might you incorporate those in one,
The sordid bulke could nere make vp his shadow.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.p: I am prescrib'd my discipline in Court!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Grimold, away! Tis my desire you leaue
The Presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I am obedient (Sir) to your desire.

sp.speaker: Gond.
sp.p: 'Slight, thou hast made a braue retreat.

sp.speaker: Vollt.
sp.l: I look'd when both of vs should taste
Of immortalitie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He that inflam'd this fire, will scorch his busie
Fingers. My Lord, it was vnkindly done
T'affront my anger thus: but I haue hope
It is your last fault.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I cannot reckon it among my faults.
Sir, you inuolue your meaning in your speech.
The world shall finde me honest.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: You are a Bridegroome now.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, make your anger knowne,
For else your frownes will cause your loyaltie
To be suspected. This night should be as smooth
And pleasant, as that to which we owe our bless'd
Natiuitie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you are great on Earth! I am meerely
Your creation. My passions doe afford
Your high delight all sympathy.
Old Time hath throwne his feathers from his heeles,
And slowly limps in's motion to prolong
This Triumph: but if Paradine affront
Hymen, and me with sullen rage, it shall
Be call'd my piety to suffer.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: How! your Excellence ought t'excuse my speech!
When your victorious sword depriu'd me of
My Father; I enter'd to captiuity,
As to th'oblique shade, where death inhabits.
Till you allowd me Hermegild; who with
His high Philosophy did make
My bondage sweete. My Father lou'd him well:
He was his noblest Seruant, and must not
For his vertues suffer, vntill your sacred tongue
Forbid me share with you in Soueraignty.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Boy, this was a bold crime. You must not giue
Me cause to chide my fond heart. Valdaura,
Vrge him to proffer friendship
Vnto Hermegild; you are powerfull
Ore his nature. I haue deseru'd to lose
My chiefe prerogatiue—

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I am too timorous to deale with anger:
If he prooue sterne of nature, my Marriage
Is my funerall. My Lord!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Paradine, I'ue an humble loue. I will
Present it first to your refusall—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I want your phrase, to make my manners seeme
Lesse rugged. All that is loue, I cherish
With such religious heate, as my Valdaura
Claimes, since our young Nuptiall—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This embracement is a sacrifice
To thee my Queene: whose deity
Consists of loue. Sit, and with your
Persons, straight intrench the Table. Some wine!
Fill in my Germane Plate; Ile drinke as when
I'm hot with victory. This to my Bride—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Sound high!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: More wine, and noise! Now Boy, I celebrate
Valdaura's health—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Bid their Instruments speake lowder.
They're afraid to wake the Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: This is legitimate blood of the rich
Corsick Grape: precious as thy teares
(My Royall Girle) when thou art penitent
To heauen. Whilest the King talkes, they drinke.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Spare me in the next, and Ile esteeme you
Courteous; so much wine will put me to the charge
Of Physicke.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Your Lordship ownes it as a prime vertue—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Shall the world bleed? but frowne, and thou renew'st
A Chaos. Maligne the pride of some farre
Easterne Queene, whom Trauellers bely,
And I will forage there, like loud thunder!
Or like the Northerne winde vpon the Maine,
Where lazie Hulkes are toss'd like chips.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.p: I merit no such complement.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Ile do't. Tis thought, I am immortall.
The chiefe of my great Ancestors, that made
A wilde incursion ore this fertill soile,
Was but a tipe of me. More wine!— Thy breath
Is as the smoke of spices. I taste thy
Melting lippes, and straight ingender kisses.
Heart! Boy, you are too rauenous!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I euer held your Maiesty my best
Example. Kisses nimbly gather'd,
The faster grow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The Lombards vse to share this sport! He kisses Thesina.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Is not your name Pigwiggin?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Pigwiggin! your Grace was wont to call me
Cunymond: I am no Faery.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Nor I the King of Faeries. 'Slight, sir, d'ye
Present me with a Cup, made, o'th bottome
Of an Akehorne, or Queene Mabbs Thimble?
Fill me a bowle, where I may swimme,
And bathe my head, then rise like Phoebus from
The Ocean, shaking my dewy Locks.
A health to Cesars memory. Boy, doe me
Iustice, or thou afrontst my Triumph!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Conrade, the King will drowne vs all!

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: Y'haue now, Sir, but the moiety of his draught.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: Though Fame lends you her Trumpet, giues you leaue
To speake your owne praise, you cannot vtter more
Then my beliefe shall warrant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Now thou whisper'st like the amorous Lute!
I am the Broome of Heauen, when th'world grows foule,
Ile sweepe the Nations into'th Sea, like dust.
Thy father was magnanimous, and great
King of the Girpides. Yet his title
Sat not so nobly on him, as my conquest.
Know, his vnkind fate, was his chiefe glory:
For it was I that slew him; and thou his
Captiu'd Daughter art my Queene.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sir, if you continue this narration,
I shall weepe.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Doe, weepe! then on my heart-strings I will thread
Thy teares in stead of Pearle: such a wealthy
Bracelet, loue would present vnto his Queene:
And she tuck vp her sleeues, to shew her gawdy wrists.
More wine! Bring vs the Bowle of Victory.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, you ingag'd your Royall word, neuer
To present that fatall obiect.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Paradine, doe not resist my pleasure.
Ile crush thee into Ayre.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I am in my ambition vertuous,
If I desire t'expire a sacrifice
To loyaltie. Sir, ruine what you made,
But doe not violate your Vow.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Hence! I shall delight in fury!
sp.stage: Enter Cunymond with a Skull, made into a drinking-Bowle.
sp.l: Welcome, the horrid Trophey of my chiefe warre!
Rhodolinda, Ile try thy fortitude.
This was thy Fathers Skull: thou shalt pledge a health
Vnto his Ghost. He drinks: all rise vp.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O fatall! my eies shrinke within my brow!
I gather Agues like the Spring, and tremble
Like the vnlick'd Lambe, newly yeand vpon
A sheete of Snow.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Hide me, Paradine! the obiect doth so
Penetrate, that when I winke, I spie it
Through my Lids.

sp.speaker: Albou.
sp.l: Tame, feeble Soule! Will she not pledge
What we doe celebrate? Returne her person—

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: Madam, the King— Strikes him, and exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The King's a Tyrant, and thou his slaue.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: That's a fauour, Signior.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: I weare it as a Iewell in my eare.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Fly, deare Valdaura; sweeten her censure
Of this act, and mediate for the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Thesina, prethee helpe me in discourse;
My wonder (Wench) doth so disturbe my speech,
I feare I shall grow dumbe.

sp.speaker: Thesi.
sp.p: The work is pious we attempt.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The harmony of your sweet tongue is his
Best physicke: diuorce him from those black thoughts,
Whil'st I imploy my vtmost skill, to win
The Queene to his imbraces. She's great of Soule,
And may determine what my fond heart laments
To prophecy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Y'are my best Countriman, kind and loyall.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: So pale and timorous! Ile sooner couple
With a Mandrake, and beget groanes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: My Royall Lord!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hah! Am I alone? Haue they all left me?
Where is my Empire? Doe I gouerne in
The vacant Ayre?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, am I lost vnto your memory?
You were wont to trust my seruice: the way
Vnto your Couch lyes here—

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: None shall be proud but I. My smiles reuiue
The dead: but when I frowne, the liuing straight
Melt into Ghosts.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.p: Lights for the King there!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Cunymond, you are too officious! The Kings
Departure must be priuat.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: The King is light enough himselfe: he needs
No Torches.

sp.speaker: Cunym.
sp.l: And heauy enough! for he seemes to reele
With his owne weight.

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: No Maskes! No Epithelamion now!
Call for a Bonesetter, for Time hath sprain'd
His feete, and goes awry.

sp.speaker: Rhodo.
sp.l: O Hermegild! a generall eclips
In Nature, would not seeme so horrid!
To cut those cordiall strings which Hymen had
But newly ty'd.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I, there's the horror! whil'st his Vowes sat warm
Vpon his Lips; his breath not mingled yet
With cooler Ayre; thus to perturbe by sterne
Practice your sweet rest, was worse then periury.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: To present my Royall Fathers Skull,
In drunken Triumph.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Take heede! you will distract your memory.
There's a Record, Time striues to lose; and Fame
To hide beneath some oblique fold in her
Thicke Volume, as loth to discredit all
Mankind. Your father valewed you next to
His interest in heauen. I'ue seene the good
Old King search for his picture in your eyes; then—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: No more: Patience is sinfull now. Thou art
Deepely read and wise: instruct me to be bold,
For Albouine hath taught me to be cruell.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: Y'are now by holy Church incorporate;
Therefore Diuinitie forbids me vse
My naturall motions. How e're I thinke
It fit, you giue him direfull cause, soone to
Repent: Repentance sure is physick for his soule.
Paradine and 's young Bride! Your excellence
Shall please that we retire: whil'st I disguize
My kind gesture, and seeme to flatter in
The Kings behalfe—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To bed soft modesty! I will my selfe
Deliuer to the Queene the King's intent.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, the King is cruell. Should you proue so
To me, I'ld soone distill my soule to teares,
And weepe an Ocean deepe enough to drowne
My sorrowes, and my selfe.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: 'Twere sterne guilt to doubt my nature. Faire Saint,
To bed, I long to lose my Youth in warme
Embraces, and ere the pearly Morne appeare,
Make thee a teeming Mother. To bed! with winged hast
Expect my presence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: How smooth appeares the Brow of Youth!

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Haile Rhodolinda! the Royall Mistresse
Of this night. Thus Albouine (our great King) bade
Me say, Y'are dearer to his eyes then light.
Though euery Bride may claime from Hymen
Priuiledge to rule her Lord, till Hesperus
Appeare, and cancell her briefe Charter.
Yet he doth humbly beg, you'le not infringe
The Lombards custome, whose Virgins neuer vow
A continence the Nuptiall night.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I yet want your meaning.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tis his chiefe hope that you will straight expect
His person in your bed.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: How! lye with him? Ile sooner choose a Mansion
In a sepulcher: There commit incest
With the raw remnant of my fathers bones:
Sooner imbrace an ayrie Incubus:
Mingle Limmes with some vlcerous Cripple,
Able to infect an Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O take heed! Take heed, faire Maiesty! let not
His rash sinne prouoke you to intend so dire
An abstinence: ere yet the wine hath lost
Th'vnruly operation. The King disclaimes
His wanton pride, and mortifies himselfe
With sullen griefe.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Canst thou suspect, I will prooue inconstant,
To what in cold temperance I determine?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Heauen auert you should approue your error.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Ile kneele, and vow with all solemnitie—

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O hold! 'twere blacke impietie in vs
To suffer such a horrid crime. You may
Informe the King of my religious loyalty,
Already I haue vs'd perswasiue speech
To reconcile this ods: but she growes wilde,
Repugnant to all mercy.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: As you esteeme your Royall selfe, or vs,
Who (when kinder Planets rul'd) were seruants
To th'vnhappy King your father; cherish
No more this anger in your brest, lest Time
Afford it growth and violence, till it
Disturbe the world.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: He councels like a sacred Oracle.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I will informe the King, your continence
You onely celebrate to this blacke night,
And giue him hope, that you'le hereafter smile,
His kinde inticements meet with equall heate,
And fertill loue. Though I'm vnhewne, and shap'd
In warre, this softens all my faculties—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Stay, Paradine; didst thou not name my Father?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: I did with a deuout remembrance!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: And thou know'st how thy good Country suffers?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I think on it, and my heart hangs heauy
On its strings; galles them with its sullen weight.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Hermegild oft receiues certificate
From some in bondage there, which writ in Prose, doe,
I'th reading into Verse dissolue: so sad
The businesse is, so fit for elegie.

sp.speaker: Hermeg.
sp.l: So sad a Requiem yet was neuer sung,
Though the hoarce Rauen, and the Whistler shrill,
The Howlet, and the euening Dorr made vp
The fatall Quire. The young men there are yoak'd
In payres, and stretch their sinnews in a Teeme,
To draw the wealthy haruest to the Grange,
Where th'insulting foe resides. The aged
(Heretofore in purple cloth'd) that dispos'd
Of Law and Iustice; are now sow'd vp
In dunghill clouts; and dwell on parched hills,
To tend the flocks; whose fleece the Victor weares
In gawdy triumph.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O harsh captiuitie! Our Country groanes!
Till now I thought the Conqueror gan to ease
Their bondage, not adde to the weight of their
Compell'd burdens.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: The King's a sterne Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Yet he hath vs'd me still with gentle power,
Ta'ne me from the cold Earth, and warm'd me in
His bosome: and Hermegild has full cause
To blesse his bounty. But you (now our Queene)
He valewes next to heauen; howe're this rash
Error striues to disgrace his loue. We are
His captiues too; heretofore not heeded
By our Starres; though we now grow tall with titles
And his fauour.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: My Lord, the King is kinde! Our memories
Were fraile, should we forget what hath so much
Pertain'd vnto our knowledge. I'm so fond
O're my Religion, I dare not taste
Ingratitude: yet giue me leaue to say,
You may mistake his loue vnto the Queene.
The dry Tartar, who yoakes his females neck
With rusty Yron, not with Carckanets
Of threaded Pearle; whom he preserues for physick
More then increase; will the first night of their
Coniunction, feast her in's imbroader'd tent;
Call her Soueraigne; and like some amorous winde,
Sport with her haire.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: But my Nuptiall the King did celebrate
In Golgotha, where Skulls, and dusty bones
Inhabit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Y'are skilfull in the deeds that appertaine
To strength and fury; but they that aime
At victory in Court, must practise smooth
And subtill Arts. Wise Fauourites doe walke
I'th darke, and vse false lights. Nay, oft disguize
Their breadth and stature; seeme lesser then they are:
For know, the slender Worme, or nimble Grig,
May wriggle downe into th' oblique, and low
Descent o'th narrow hole; whilst th'oregrowne Snake
Peepes at the brimme, but ne're can view the bottome.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thinke on thy Country, Paradine! Is there
In Story no mention of some great Soule,
That did his Country prize aboue his owne
Mortalitie, and dy'd to gaine his Nation Freedome?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The Noble Brutus for his Countreys health,
Made Cesar bleed; Cassius was heroique too,
And had in warre loud Fame, which he increas'd
By mingling in this Act.— Tis wrought with skill,
And apt leasure. His thoughts grow numerous,
And ingender horrid shapes; such as fright
His fancy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Paradine, good night!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Hymen and your Bride, will blame your tardy
Seruice. Sweet Lord, a thousand times good night.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: False vnto me! when Thunder wakes the dead:
When the Skie looks swarthy: the clouds like inke
In water powr'd: when the Earth seemes to stand
As in a gloomy shade. When the winde blowes
Till it growes hoarce: till it conuert
And sprinkle Seas euen to a Dew; then I
Shall try the King, and fathome his wide Soule.
If he start, complaine of his mortalitie,
Kneele oft; and pray aloud, as Heauen
Were deafe: if thus, I will conclude him false.
For horrid stormes that Tyrants waking keepe,
Doe rock the noble Conscience safe asleepe. Exit.

div.head: Act the third. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I knew your Excellence did visit me
For mirth and laughter.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So early vp? Your Lord is temperate.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I should like their tempers better, if she
Were downe, and her Lord vp.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.p: Fye, Thesina, your tongue's vnruly.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: The morning might haue shewne me too for mirth,
Had not the false King made the night so sad.
Black fancy flye!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: She moues as she were sicke, this skirmish has
Much weakened her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Dost thou call't a skirmish?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I, Madam, a French skirmish; where th' onset
Is hot and fiery, but the retreat cold and tame.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Madam, the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: He greets your Excellence in a smooth phrase,
And begs, you will permit his early visit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I'ld rather lose my eyes then see him.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: When you did triumph in your fathers Court,
My entreaty then had power to alter
Your commands; reward my young seruice
With kindnesse to your selfe. When the tall
Cedar falls, with burly weight it strikes
The neighbouring shrubs, low, into the ground:
So we that spring like Rushes neere your roote,
Must in your death receiue a funerall.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What's this? D'ye moralize?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The King may haue his anger warranted.
For heauen forbids such wilde diuision
'Tweene those whom holy Church vnites.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Harke, Thesina! She has been gossiping
With the holy Sisters: she preaches to me
Of Matrimoniall zeale. Troth Valdaura,
If thy husband doe infuse such schisme,
Ile practise a diuorce.

sp.speaker: Thesina.
sp.l: We Court Ladies grow so squeamish after
We haue tasted Man. Your Maiesty may
Much profit her behauiour, if you
A while deuide her from her Lord.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: So soone? Ere Time permits them second
Their imbraces?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I Hermegild. If those imbraces doe
Include such high delight, such rapsody;
She makes me enuious then; since all my hopes
Are widdowed by the King. To night, Valdaura,
You are to sleepe beneath my Roofe. This I
Impose as a command.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Is not this a harsh compulsion?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, I willingly obey it. But as
Y'are Noble, vse your ablest skill, t'instruct
The Queene how of her anger to dispose
A safer way, then 'gainst the King.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas! I'ld rather cut my Eye-lids off
To preuent sleepe then lose one minute that
Could aduantage a designe so pious.
And be it part of your kinde charity,
T' indeere me to your Lord. Tis all the pride
In my ambition to doe him seruice.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Sir, he already knowes your worth, and thinks
Your friendship precious. Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I kisse your faire hands. The King already come?
I must seeme pensiue as the night.

div.stage: Enter Albouine, Paradine, Cunymond, Frollo, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: She's lost, my Boy: blowne from my fist: her wings
Haue gather'd wind: they flye (like those of Time)
Swiftly forward, but neuer backe returne.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sir, I haue hope, she will repent this breach
Of duty, and court your Royall smiles agen.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Is it a sinne to drinke? Nature has giuen
To fishes a prerogatiue, greater
Then we inioy. They can euer tipple
And not be drunke.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Fishes are dumb (Sir) they neuer fox themselues
With talke.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Slaue! thy mirth is treacherous! Paradine!
Thou hast consum'd to night the wealth of loue,
Wasted thy lips in moyst kisses, imbrac'd
A warmth, that would giue life to marble.
Whilst I, (like the solitary Phoenix)
Expect no heate but in my funerall flame:
And striue t'ingender of my selfe. Yet Boy,
Thou canst not make me enuious; thou art more
Delightfull; then my Rodolinda's sinnes.
Let me suruay those blue circles: his lids
Fall downe, as if weighty Plummets hung on
Their sinnes. Thou art not temperate. Preserue
Thy deare eyes. Loue was pictur'd blind, because
It makes men blinde. I hugge thee as my health—

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He bruis'd me in his armes. Can loue expresse
Such violence, and yet be false? Hermegild
Still whispers in my eare, the King doth hate
Thee, Paradine. But Hermegild is read in all
The Arts of Court, and striues perhaps
My sence to poyson with leane iealousie.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sweet Lord! Y' appeare blushing like the Morne!
Something your Bride and you haue done t' increase
The number of the Worthies.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: He courts me too! I want a Perspectiue,
To draw these distant figures neere my sight.
I ne're shall sleepe agen.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hermegild, thy aspect shewes ominous!
How thriues our embasie?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I haue consum'd my breath, till I grew faint,
And wept to inuite her mercy; but teares
Were spilt like water in the Forge, onely
T' inrage the fire. She doth abiure your visit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Harsh, Iron, nature!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The King seemes fetter'd in his lims: he wreathes
His armes, as if he meant to bruise his heart.
And Paradine doth find my charmes predominant.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: He that drinks, forfeits his mortalitie!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: How Sir, must we not drink?

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Souldier, to keepe thy bladder moyst, I will
Permit thee gape i'th mornings face, and catch
Her mizzling teares.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If you'll extirpate this vice of drinking,
Giue order for a priuy search i'th the Ocean;
There dwell the greatest drinkers. The Whale (Sir)
Drinks deeper let's hale her on shore, and impownd her
In a Cesterne.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Good! we will imbarke for Sea. I presse thee vp
For this imployment.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Stay (Sir) ere I ingage my selfe in new
Seruices, pay me for my old. You rest
Vpon my Ticket, six thousand Duckats;
And I haue not seene your Maiesties face
In any other metall, but your owne
Flesh and blood these three moneths.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Thou grumblest like a gray Wolfe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Tis then for hunger, Sir.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Captaine, you mistake the King. He's Royall
As his blood, and liberall as the Sunne
That shines on all. This vnruly breath, where
The Citie meete in councell, might perhaps
Blow their Purse-strings loose, so fill the Exchequer.
And then you shall number your pay with your owne
Fingers.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: I will out-rore thunder, or the Cannon!
Must they still walke in wealthy Furres; whilst men
Of merit here are cloth'd in Cabidge leaues?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Grimold, you indanger your friends.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: My Lord, giue losers leaue to speake. I'ue lost
My youth and blood ith' warres, and I want food,
A reuerend Asse beares my wife and her young egges
In Paniers vp and downe the streets. I trauaile
Like a Tartar, with all my family
About me. Nay, nay, nay! you would be gon!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Art thou not yet dead?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: You must not moue, till y'haue paid me. I know,
You may be angry with more safety then I.
Bid some Colossus of your Guard cleaue me
With his Falchon; yet I shall steale a passage
Ore the blacke Riuer, when Charon slumbers,
And fright your Grace.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I dare not strike thee (old man) lest thou shouldst fall
To dust, and choke me.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Good King, pay me. I loue thy Grace:
And will fight for thee, whilst I'ue motion left
To stirre a feather. My want constraines me to't.
By this hand, I'm faine to eate Branne and Parsley
Like a tame Rabbit.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Lend me your eare, Captaine!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: You'll intice me now t'enter into bond?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You look indeed like a young heire. Well, Sir,
Valew me according to my true rate.
I am your friend. You make ill choice of howers
For helpe of your designe. The King hath now
Sad and tumultuous thoughts about his heart.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Great men are alwayes sad, when they should pay
Their debts.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, you interpret ill. Grow more sober,
Then challenge all my power in your behalfe.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: He that receiues a kindnes from the Diuell,
Shall bee sure to lose by his gaines.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Captaine, you should chuse a luckier minute:
The King is now in loue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: With the Queene.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In loue with his owne wife! that's held incest
In Court: varietie is more luscious.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Be powerfull in thy speech, my Paradine,
Yet gentle too. She is the Starre that rules
My faculties.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The Queen will blesse your temperance, & repent.
Hermegild is too busie: he must be more
At leasure, and I more actiue.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Hermegild, weare thy sences neere vs—

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Your Maiesty has a fraile memory
To forget me so soone—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: You'll forfeit me, and the Kings mercy! away!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Tis no piece of vnkindnesse to wish thee
In hell, for all thy friends dwell there. Th'ast none
Vpon the earth. Gentlemen will you be open to me?

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: In all parts, Sir, but our purses.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Draw neere! let vs communicate our hearts!
Does not that wealth, which you disburse for powders,
Perfumes, clothes, and physicke for the face,
Returne with gaine?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Expound your Riddle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Haue you not each a Mistresse that maintaines
You in expence and riot? Hah? Fame giues
It out, you smooth Gallants are much oblig'd
Vnto the sinnes of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Conrade can prattle somewhat, Sir, to that
Purpose.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.l: Good faith you do me wrong. I'ue worne, Sir,
A Ladies slipper in my hat, or so.
Frollo is the man that gets their Pendants,
Armelets, Rings, and all the Toyes of valew.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: Excuse me, sir, not I. Signior Cunymond
Has all the voyce at Court. We know, Sir, when,
And where, a certaine Dutchesse, Sir;
You copulate with Titles, you.
The Heralds are your Bawds.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: Hold! grow particular in such a Theame as this!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I must be furnish'd too.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: With a Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yes, inquire me out some old Land-Carack.
I am content to stretch my loynes for a
Pension.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: At what rate doe you valew your selfe?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: I was neuer pawn'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: How, Captaine!

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: In this leane age, we valew all things
According to the rate, they pawne for.

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.l: But we must know, how much you would receiue
In price of your actiuitie?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.p: You must neuer stray after fresh pasture.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Some eight; I, I, eight hundred Crownes a yeere will doe't.
I am desirous of no more then will
Maintaine my Genet, and my Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Your excuse procur'd, tis fit you now tell,
How farre in your defence I may ingage
My honour: is not your flesh a little tainted!
Are you not vnwholsome?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: O death, no; no, no, no! Do not thinke I haue
A conscience so ill bred, to put my selfe
Vpon a Lady, when vnfit for the affaire.

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.l: Well, Captaine, now with your own eies suruay
Your limmes; what vse can a Lady haue
Of you? To propagate the Cough o'th lungs?

sp.speaker: Frollo.
sp.p: Or beget Cripples, to people an Hospitall?

sp.speaker: Conrad.
sp.l: Or produce another Nation that may
Wage fierce battaile 'gainst the Cranes?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Yet I can follow your bodies with rough
Motion, and not shed my limmes by the way—

sp.speaker: Cuny.
sp.p: I told ye, he'ld make a ieast on't.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: But I will kick ye in earnest,— kick ye
For my exercise and warmth— till my toes
Grow crooked—

div.stage: Enter Valdaura, reading to her selfe, then Albouine, Hermegild.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Pursue Valdaura, Sir.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I hate these Iiggeries.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: You know, I am materiall in my speech,
Full of duty; you want the silken garbe,
That must indeere you to the Ladies eyes.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: Yet I am louing in my drinke.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Greet her kindly, Sir: tis Paradines Bride.
You haue not seene her since she indeuour'd
To increase the number of your subiects,
With losse of her virginitie.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Rhodolinda doth so ingrosse my loue,
That on other Ladies I'ue but little
To bestow.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Sir, practise but your Courtship here. In troth
You must affect the amorous Cringe, gestures
Smooth and pliant; it will neuer doe else.
I'ue heard the Queene complaine, you are too rough:
And what these Ladies doe obserue, will take
A sudden flight vnto her eare. Strike but
Their sences gently with your tongue. Often
Flatter'em, and with a vigorous breath;
They'll then implore the Queene in your behalfe:
And, Sir, th' indeuour of their praise will soone
Procure your peace.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: If they would soften Rhodolinda's heart,
And reconcile me to her smiles, I would
Grow fond, and dally then with all the Sex.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Begin your triall. If you salute this,
(And other Ladies too) with some impression on
Their lipps; with managing their fingers thus,—
With seysure on her wrist; as if you had
Some businesse with her Pulse: then you inchant.
Be flexiue in your smiles, and wanton like,
Seeke pictures in their eyes: and when they moue,
Then with personall conduct, guide their feet.
'Mongst them you cannot seeme too cheape. They will
Admire you for't, and sing your prayses to
The Queene.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.p: I shall be taught to spin, and starch!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The engin's now compact; each wheele doth moue
With silent screwes. The Mole's the subtle Pioner:
For when she vndermines the earth, her slow
Motion makes no noise. Exit.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Y'are deuout, Vauldaura. Teach me to pray:
We haue no leasure for't in warre; and 't has
Been long time out of fashion here in Court.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I feare I make some breach of duty with
Your Excellence, to hinder thus
The passage of your Royall thoughts.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You teach me now, t'excuse my owne abrupt
Demeanour; but I can doe't. My harsh Queene
(Whom the perspicuous Eye of heauen forgiue)
Doth much mistake the posture of my limmes,
And gesture of my tongue among your Sex.
I neuer vse, like rugged Polypheame,
To dandle Cubs. Thus, I can gently touch
A Ladies lips— yet make no battery on
Her teeth. Was it not an ayrie pressure?
Tell my proud Queene, I'ue lost my Iron garbe,
And now am growne thus fond and smooth.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O Royall Sir, her cruelty hath put
My eyes vnto th'expence of many teares.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: I, but in vaine! Those clouds must weep apace,
That meane to penetrate the Marble, or
The Flint. I weare no Gauntlet on my hand,
Why should you thinke that I would bruise
Your fingers with my touch— Sports with her hand.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is this Paradines Garden?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I Madam, and your Excellence may finde
A sudden growth, in all that shadowes vs.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hah I looke there!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What is 't your eyes so eagerly discerne?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: The King! How sportfull he is growne? how full
Of amarous game and dalliance?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: I spie Valdaura there: but is that the King?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thou dost inquire, t'affront my sight.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: You must informe the Queene of this: Say, I
Am smooth, and musicall, and trim, and that
I talke no more of warre, nor drinke.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Tis my duty to vrge all circumstance,
That may credit you in her esteeme.

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: It is a piece of courtship to salute
At parting— Kisses her. exit Valdaura.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Is that a safe coniunction in so hot a climate!

sp.speaker: Albo.
sp.l: Hell and death! What raw discipline is this?
I should conduct her in her way— Exit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: So violent in pursuit of your game?
Let's follow, Hermegild?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Not for all the Sunne beholds in's iourney
Through the world—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why? be nimble in thy speech!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It shewes but silly art in industry,
To seeke what you would not finde.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I pre thee grow particular! Dost thinke
They purpose ought ith' darke? or, was this same
But ceremonious forme! such a greeting
As courtship will admit in publike interuiew?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: The King was neuer giuen to complement,
You know. As for Valdaura—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I thinke that she is chaste, but—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Doe not inuolue thy language thus
In periods of suspence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I wish the King had not deseru'd to be
Depriu'd of your soft imbraces, then
He might haue kept his constitution tame.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O, is it so?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It ill becomes the garbe of Maiesty,
To run thus neighing (like a riotous Horse)
After each female that he spies.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why, does he vse it?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Madam, you question me, as if what I
Declare, were to your knowledge new and strange.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: By heauen and so it is.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: O my officious Soule! must it be my crime
To giue the information vp? would I
Had knowne the King was here, you should haue made
Another path, your walke.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Hermegild, you did mis-spend that breath.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Alas, you had enough of griefe before.
This addition will but shew a tyranny
In fate and me. It works with hight, like new
Mighty wine! as if 't would split the Caske.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: O periur'd, black, adulterous King! affront
My Fathers Ghost? Disturbe his Ashes in
His tombe? When drunk with pride, he mock'd me with
The gawdy title of a Queene, and now
I am become a stale for all his lust.
Valdaura too! so pure of heart (forsooth)
That she would blush to see her own hand, if nak'd:
They are proscrib'd. Know, Hermegild,
Our Country shall be free.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This is a noble rage! Heauen knowes how I
Haue grieu'd at your decay of soule. 'T was my
Sad feare, that all the angry sparkes, which were
By Iustice kindled in your brest, had been
Extinguish'd quite, now they grow vp in flames.
You now like Phoebus shew, when he hath wash'd
His face with Dew. Your influence doth infuse
A noble heate, such as would motion giue
Vnto aged Statues; make them pluck vp
Their Mossie feet, and walke.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou giu'st my sences pride! What in this great
Businesse wilt thou doe, t' incourage hope?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I will mingle poyson in my Inke, write
With a Rauens Quill! 't will be a fatall
Scripture: and shall charme like to those wise Iigs
The Syrens sing. Some must direction beare
T' our Pensioners, that in our Country rule
The sterne Edicts of Law: some to Martiall
Spirits, who with their able skill doe leade
Those Regiments, the King hath garison'd
I'th bordering Townes. They shall reuolt, my Queene,
And seate thee in thy Fathers Chaire: they must
Be drunke with the Elixir of my Gold.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: When first I chose thee out for this great work,
I saw thee thorow a Perspectiue reuerss'd;
For thou didst seeme much lesser then thou art.
Kneele, and be happy!— Before
The Genius of this place, and what is here
Immortall, I vow to assist with my
Most actiue skill, all thy designements 'gainst
The King; and when my iust hopes are finish'd,
To be thy Wife. Such as doe periur'd prooue,
Lightning will surely clothe with subtle flames,
And they shall burne like glimmering Tapers
In darke hell: pale, and sickly as that fire
The Ghost of Nero makes.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: This new ambition hath so exalted
All my faculties, that I seeme taller
Kneeling, then when I stood. But here with strict
Solemnitie I vow to teach my Soule
New wayes of merit: to reuenge with sterne,
And horrid wrath, the Kings proud tyranny.
To make your Greatnesse absolute, and high,
Or sinke my selfe lower then a Plummet,
In the Baltick Sea. Should I not this performe,
The Starres would fall like Cinders on my head:
And winds imprison'd in the Earth; breake forth,
In a wilde ruine, and shake me into sand:
Then blow me in your Eyes; where if in teares
You drowne me, I am intomb'd in Pearle: and then
My obsequies requite my death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Enough. I proffet to thy lip, the first
Taste of my affection— They kisse, then rise.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: 'T was moyst and luscious! I will cherish this
Indeerement. Trees that tallest grow, doe take
The deepest roote; so I must first sinke low
Ith' Earth; and after climbe to fathome clouds.
First, praise her mimick laughter: when she weepes,
Then gather vp with couetous regard
Her teares for scatter'd Pearle. Licke her spittle
From the ground: this disguiz'd humilitie
Is both the swift, and safest way to pride—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Sure, Hermegild, I haue amaz'd thy sence,
Thou look'st like some ore-growne Fiend, chain'd vp
Within a silent caue. Let vs retire, and Ile
Discouer how I'ue practis'd my reuenge.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I proiect to make you mighty! You shall
Ascend my beautious Soueraigne, till you
Can reach the Moone, and pick those seeds of light
(The lesser Stars) from forth their wandring Spheares;
To weare as new imbroadery on your sleeue.
I long to heare your fatall Arts. Let's mix
Our sences, and contriue. A womans will,
Is not so strong in anger, as her skill.

div.stage: Enter Paradine, a Gentleman and Page.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: You bring no letters from Cracouia, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: None, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Nor from Sienna?

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.l: Your Lordship in those few, receiues th'intire
Purpose of my iourney.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Alas, my Countrymen! Captiuitie
Is hoarce, they haue more griefs then tongue: they speak
Not loud enough to wake the eare of heauen.
Henceforth to Hermegild bid them direct
Their sighs; for I'm so dull, so weary, and
Neglectfull of ambitious ends, that I
Shall lose my strength, and fauour with the King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: My noble Lord, our prayers will ouer-rule that prophecy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You may expect, whilst I am able to
Performe. Boy, bespeake the Gentleman a free
And bounteous welcome. Sir, I will hasten
Your dispatch.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.p: My Lord; I haue tyr'd my selfe in your search.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The faire Thesina? You are rarely here
A visitant! Where haue you left my Bride?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: With the Queene, my Lord, who is so fond
Of her attendance, she'le scarce allow her space
To winke in her owne seruice, and to night
She lyes within her chamber.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Hah! so soone deuided! Th'approching night
Should helpe to second our imbraces.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Y'are now to trust my Art. For Valdaura
Sent me t'expresse her ioy, i'th deliuery
Of this message. You shall lye with her to night.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: How can my faith admit of this, since she
Is billited where the Queene sleepes?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Ile perfect my assurance; so you'll please
T'obey what I inioyne. When you approach
The Spheare, where your bright Phoebe rules, doe not
Occasion so much noyse, as shall expresse
You liuing. You must not speake to her, nor
By your gestures, inuite her speech. All this
Performe, lest you should wake the Queene.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To be dumbe in copulation! This is
A fine receipt to get a silent Girle.
But I shall prooue obedient.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: And (Sir) as y'are mercifull to Ladies
(Ripe in growth) doe not breathe too loud, lest we
Ith' neighbouring roome, ore-heare the harmony,
And sinne in wishes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Feare not, Thesina: I shall be temperate.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: But you young souldiers are so boysterous,
You'll thinke anon, y'are battering some Towne-wall.
Follow, Sir, Ile direct ye to the place,
Where, when the darke howre arriues, you must
Addresse your visit.

div.head: Act the fourth. Scene first.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: The early Lark climbes higher then his voice;
And whispers into Phoebus eare, a glad
Welcome; who smiles, and seemes to prophecy
A gawdy day. Valdaura? Madame? speake,
Sweet Lady! or, if for concealement of
Our stolne rapture you silence still assume;
Yet rise, and blesse my eye-sight with thy faire
Presence. Come, and eclipse the enuious day!
Not talke ith' businesse, nor yet behold
The ground we till, as if we both were blinde
And dumbe. Ile no more by stealth ingender;
Cripples are got thus. Kind Valdaura, speake!
sp.stage: A hand is thrust out betweene the Arras.
sp.l: See, a new day breakes in her hand! These are
The rosie fingers of the Morne!
Hah! the Queene! Valdaura! Bride, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: In vaine thou call'st. The Cannons Iron throat,
Although high mounted on you 'Pinacle,
Scarce could reach her eare. She's in Pauia now,
Two Leagues situate from hence.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Thou art mysterious as an Oracle!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: I sent her thither, with pretence she should
Suruay the modell of a Garden-worke.
But 'twas done, that Thesina might intice
With apter leasure, thy person to my bed.
At noone thy wife returnes.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: I'ue mistaken then my warme embraces,
And sinn'd with thee th' adulterous Queene!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Thou hast inioy'd what Albouine with all
His Royall sighs, his teares swolne bigger then
His eyes, despair'd to merit.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: O horror! gape, rugged Earth! Suck me in
Like some old Pyramid, whose ponderous limmes
Haue been thy burden since the Flood, and now
Their owne foundation sinke. Could you make
No choice to quench your rauenous lust, but me?
Where were the broad-chin'd Zwitzers of your Guard?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: This (Paradine) denotes a melting braine:
Which out of vulgar pity I forgiue.
'Twas not the wanton taste of thy smooth limmes,
That could prouoke me vse this stratagem.
But loue of my reuenge. I'ue strongly now
Ingag'd thy power, to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Which do: and ere the Sun arriue ith' West;
Or with disheuell'd haire, my vestments torne
(As if I'd wandred thorow some Hathorne hedge)
I will approach the Tyrant, acquaint him
With this deed, and call my owne adultery
Thy fowle rape.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Who 's within there, hoa! My Hogs-head's empty.
I was not borne with so much braines, as would
Bedew a clout, that my cold Nosthrill stopt.
These Court smocks containe the very Deuill.
Good heauen! how leane should I haue made my heart
With studious thoughts, ere I the skill had reach'd
Of such a damn'd proiection.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Collect thy scatter'd thoughts. What thy respect
To thy captiu'd Country, could ne're charme thee
To reuenge; be prompted to, by a kinde
Affection of thy owne deare life: reuenge
Vpon a Tyrant; One, that loues not me,
Nor thee; vnlesse in speech: he hath a smooth
Tongue, but a rugged heart. My Hermegild
Perceiues this truth, and can deliuer it
With all the pride of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: Sure Time growes humerous with age: for things
Doe differ much from the sincerenesse of
Their first creation. I will goe weepe
Till I am blind—

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, Paradine. If thou dost mocke my hopes
With a slow motion in this iust designe,
Expect to finde my anger fatall. Ile to
The King, and make a forfeiture of both
Our liues: but if with hardy sinnewes thou dost march
To 's Throat, and slit the swarthy Pipe, I'le call
Thee then my Souldier. Besides thy Countries thanks,
Thou shalt enioy me for thy Queene, thy Wife,
Paradine.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: New Arts, t'inuolue imagination!
How can this be, and my owne wife strongly
Possess'd of health and nature!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Would'st thou imbrace so eminent a blisse,
Without some danger to thy soule?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: My memory betrayes my skill! I know
There are a thousand wayes to discard her,
From this foule, durty Orbe.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Alas, good easie Soule! She'le ne're be miss'd
Among the liuing. Know, Valdaura's false.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.p: How! False!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: She is a open whore, and hath taught me
This Art of lust.

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: More horrible then Hell!
Now furnish but my hands with an Hower-glasse,
And a long Dart, then seat me on some rotten
Monument for the picture of leane Death.
Make me the common Executioner
Of Nature. For ere long I shall become
The Sextons Pensioner to fill his Graues.
Valdaura false!

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Wilt thou thus leaue me in a wilde suspence,
Whether I shall finde thy courage actiue?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: For credit of your owne humanitie,
Doe not infringe the vulgar priuiledge
Due to all hearts. Giue me but leaue to thinke;
And ne're doubt your businesse! Though I'm a young
Sinner; yet I shall soone inquire the way
To hell. Tis a continu'd thorow-fare
From this Climate thither. Or let me but
Delay my iourney, till the triuiall rage
Of Christian Princes, meete in horri'd battaile;
And then I shall haue company enough:
Whole throngs to choke the throat of hell.
Good night, Madame.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Ere yet the Morne 's faire cheek hath lost her teares,
Dost call it night?

sp.speaker: Parad.
sp.l: To me it seemes the Eye of heauen doth winke.
All things are cloath'd in darkenesse, blacke as your
Designe.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: Stay, for else my rage will not permit
That we suruiue another meeting.
If thou suspectst we are too loud, I will
Distill my thoughts into thy eare.

div.stage: She hangs about his necke whispering.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Though t'assist my great hopes with opportune
Induction, I consented to this act:
Yet now I chide my fond spirits. For who
Dares trust th' vnruly appetite of youth?
What I decreed she should but taste, she may
Delight to surfeit on. It shewes fulsome!
Here's the precious medicine that must restore
Health to my hopes. Follow, gentle Lady.
You see 'em now?

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Fall, fall, you thicke and spungy clouds, vntill
You choke my sight. Doe not my eyes begin
To bleed at this obiect?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Marke how close they meete: what variety
They vse in lust: now she hath melted quite his lips
With her hot breath, she hangs vpon his eare.
Suruay their gestures still. Now they depart.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Ile summon all the hierarchy of heauen
To censure'em!

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Who knowes but they are gone to wallow in
Their actiue sweats agen? Alas, pure soule!
You perceiue these figures no Idea,
No obiect of the minde, or ayre incorporate
To cheate imaginary view.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Was this the cause, that made th'adulterous Queene
So strictly vrge my swift iourney vnto
Pauia?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I, and the motiue that prouok'd my soft
Conscience to hasten your returne, that you
Might tell sad tales to heauen. For I
(That still was nourc'd vpon a Sybils Lap)
Who with prophetick Milke did nourish me,
Can deepely guesse at th'ominous portent
Of sinne. I hate such loose-rein'd Stallions;
Such lasciuious harmony in guilt.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: So soone proue false? ere the celebration
Of our marriage Rites were fully ended?
Ere the Sunne in's iourney o're this Region
Had twice beheld thus incorporate
By holy Church, and smil'd vpon the hopes
Of our increase?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: I, there's a contemplation that would crack
Euen heart-strings made of wyer. Hymens Taper
But newly lighted, and he with rude breath
Blowes from the quickning weeke the gawdy flame.
Then in the darke, thus wilfully misse-takes
Your bed, and riots 'tweene vnlawfull sheets.
Horror! horror!

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O my sinister Starres! Thus I shall weepe
Till I haue emptied all my veines.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: What should such white and harmelesse soules as we
Do crawling o're this mountainous Earth? Alas,
We cannot drinke, till we intoxicate
A Whale, nor surfeit, till our greazie cheekes
Doe swell like Th'vdders of a Cow. Nor can
We kneele like warme Idolaters, vnto
The rusty metall in a bag. We want
These helpes to gaine vs honour and esteeme.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I haue a resolute intent to die,
And seeke my Mansion in a purer Orbe.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: But ere you doe begin your last walke, ith' path
Inuisible, some meritorious act
(Ioynd to the Charter of your Creed) should helpe
T'assure your future blisse.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: O name it, ere my sorrow shall decay
Me strength: for I would mix abilitie
With will.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Your Lord (foule, and sinfull as mortalitie
Can make him) Salamander-like, shall bathe
In blue fires, vnlesse by sufferance here
On earth, he penetrate the hearth of heauen,
And soften their decree. It will be call'd
Your merit to reuenge his crime, euen with his death.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: Would you haue me kill him?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Since I am strict to vertue, I must needs
Be cruell vnto vice. Let him not liue
To increase his owne guilt, and betray more
Ladies.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: But shall I iustice take from powerfull Heauen,
And vse it with such cruelty?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Beleeue me skill in sacred Oracles,
My piety to warrant the designe
Nor will I fright the frailty of your Sex,
With horrid circumstance; he shall not bleed,
This Violl doth containe a draught; which if
In's vsuall Beueridge powr'd, will coozen him
Of's leprous soule in his most quiet sleepe.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: I doe suspect my courage!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Tak't, faire Pupill! think on't in your prayers.
If you but enioy one single motion
That informes you it is good: do't with pride
And boldnesse masculine. Distinguish thus
Its operation. Foure dayes must fully take
Their room ith' Kalendar, ere it effect
Our hopes. Before that houre ariue, he must
Be wrought to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Vald.
sp.l: The Violl liquid Lead containes, or else
Some farre more ponderous Metall: for whilst
I beare it thus, the wieght seemes to infuse
A Palsey in my hand. I tremble like
A string touch'd on my Lute.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: It is the Fiend, that would dehort you from
A pious act: trust not his whispring charmes
But with a hardy courage, (more then is
Naturall in thy modest Sex) proceed
To merit heauen. And now requite my forward zeale
To vertue, with concealement of my name,
